questions.text: The biochemical basis of scurvy is:
questions.solution:
Option A: Vitamin C deficiency can lead to scurvy. Proline and lysine hydroxylases are required for the postsynthetic modification of procollagen to collagen. Both this enzyme requires vitamin C. So signs of vitamin C deficiency include skin changes, fragility of blood capillaries, gum decay, tooth loss, and bone fracture, which can be attributed to impaired collagen synthesis(leading to delayed wound healing) and psychological changes that can be attributed to impaired synthesis of catecholamines.

Option B: Increased keratinization of epithelium is seen in vitamin A deficiency.

Option C: Prothrombin and several other proteins of the blood clotting system(factors VII, IX and X, and proteins C and S) each contain 4 to 6 γ-carboxyglutamate residues. γ-Carboxyglutamate chelates calcium ions and so permits the binding of the blood-clotting proteins to membranes. In vitamin K deficiency or in the presence of warfarin, an abnormal precursor of prothrombin(preprothrombin) containing little or no γ-carboxyglutamate and incapable of chelating calcium, is released into the circulation.

Option D: Calcium has no role in collagen formation or scurvy.

questions.text: Respiratory distress syndrome is caused by the deficiency of?
questions.solution:
Option A: Phosphatidylethanolamine(cephalin) and phosphatidylserine(found in most tissues) are also found in cell membranes and differ from phosphatidylcholine only in that ethanolamine or serine, respectively, replaces choline. Phosphatidylserine also plays a role in apoptosis(programmed cell death).

Option B: Sphingomyelins are found in the outer leaflet of the cell membrane lipid bilayer and are particularly abundant in specialized areas of the plasma membrane known as lipid rafts. They are also found in large quantities in the myelin sheath that surrounds nerve fibers. They are believed to play a role in cell signaling and in apoptosis. Sphingomyelins contain no glycerol and on hydrolysis they yield a fatty acid, phosphoric acid, choline and sphingosine. The combination of sphingosine plus fatty acid is known as ceramide, a structure also found in the glycosphingolipids.

Option C: Dipalmitoyl lecithin(Dipalmitoyl phosphatidyl choline) is a very effective surface-active agent and a major constituent of the surfactant preventing adherence, due to surface tension, of the inner surfaces of the lungs. Its absence from the lungs of premature infants causes respiratory distress syndrome.

Option D: Phosphatidic acid is a precursor of phosphatidylglycerol, which in turn gives rise to cardiolipin. This phospholipid is found only in mitochondria and is essential for the mitochondrial function. Decreased cardiolipin levels or alterations in its structure or metabolism cause mitochondrial dysfunction in aging and in pathologic conditions including heart failure, hypothyroidism and Barth syndrome(cardioskeletal myopathy)

choices.text: E1: Pyruvate dehydrogenase E2: Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase
E1: Pyruvate Decarboxylase E2: Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase
E1: Pyruvate carboxylase E2: Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase
E1: Pyruvate dehydrogenase E2: Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase

questions.text: This multienzyme complex converts Pyruvate to Acetyl CoA. Identify E1 and E2:
questions.solution:
Pyruvate undergoes oxidative decarboxylation to acetyl-CoA, catalyzed by a multienzyme complex that is associated with the inner mitochondrial membrane. This pyruvate dehydrogenase complex is analogous to the α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex of the citric acid cycle.

Pyruvate is decarboxylated by the pyruvate dehydrogenase component of the enzyme complex to a hydroxyethyl derivative of the thiazole ring of enzyme-bound thiamin diphosphate, which in turn reacts with oxidized lipoamide, the prosthetic group of dihydrolipoyl transacetylase, to form acetyl lipoamide. In thiamin(vitamin B1) deficiency, glucose metabolism is impaired and there is significant(and potentially life-threatening) lactic and pyruvic acidosis.

Acetyl lipoamide reacts with coenzyme A to form acetyl-CoA and reduced lipoamide. The reaction is completed when the reduced lipoamide is reoxidized by a flavoprotein, dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase, containing flavin adenine dinucleotide(FAD). Finally, the reduced flavoprotein is oxidized by NAD+, which in turn transfers reducing equivalents to the respiratory chain.

The overall reaction is:

Pyruvate + NAD+ + CoA → Acetyl-CoA + NADH + H+ + CO2

So Option A is correct.

questions.text: Among these, insoluble dietary fibre is?
questions.solution:
Foods contain a wide variety of other polysaccharides that are collectively known as nonstarch polysaccharides; they are not digested by human enzymes and are the major component of dietary fiber. Examples are cellulose from plant cell walls(a glucose polymer) and inulin, the storage carbohydrate in some plants (a fructose polymer)

Two types of dietary fibers:

Soluble fibers: Dissolved in water & form gel, Exa…Pectins, gums, mucilages. Found in fruits & legumes

Insoluble fibers: Absorb water & swell up, Exa…Cellulose, hemicellulose, lignin. Present in leafy vegetables & whole grains

Cellulose is the chief constituent of plant cell walls. It is insoluble and consists of β-d-glucopyranose units linked by β1 → 4 bonds to form long, straight chains strengthened by cross-linking hydrogen bonds. Mammals lack any enzyme that hydrolyzes the β1 → 4 bonds and so cannot digest cellulose. It is the major component of dietary fiber. Microorganisms in the gut of ruminants and other herbivores can hydrolyze the linkage and ferment the products to short-chain fatty acids as a major energy source. There is some bacterial metabolism of cellulose in the human colon.

Option A: Lignin: Aromatic alcohol, Antioxidant action, found in fruits

Option C: Mucilage consisting of polysaccharides containing hexose and pentose sugars and uronic acid, secreted by many plants.

Option B: Pectin occurs in fruits; it is a polymer of galacturonic acid linked α1 → 4, with some galactose an/or arabinose branches and is partially methylated. Also considered as dietary fiber.

Option D: Hemicellulose: Polymer of Pentoses, Hexoses & Uronic acid, Insoluble in water

questions.text: The amount of T in a given sample of DNA is 28%. What will be the amount of G?
questions.solution:
The observation of Chargaff that in DNA molecules the concentration of deoxyadenosine(A) nucleotides equals that of thymidine(T) nucleotides (A = T), while the concentration of deoxyguanosine(G) nucleotides equals that of deoxycytidine(C) nucleotides(G = C).

So if the amount of T in a given sample of DNA is 28%, then the amount of A is also 28%, the rest 44% is G & C. G and C are equal so the amount of G is 22 % & amount of C is also 22%.

So Option C is correct.

questions.text: The condition shown in the figure is most likely due to:
questions.solution:
Option A: Niacin deficiency can lead to pellagra. Pellagra is characterized by photosensitive dermatitis. As the condition progresses, there is depressive psychosis and possibly diarrhea. Untreated pellagra is fatal.

Pellagra is common when the staple diet is maize, due to low tryptophan content & bound form of niacin which is unavailable to the body.

Pellagra is a multifactorial disease. Although the nutritional etiology of pellagra is well established and either tryptophan or niacin prevents or cures the disease, additional factors, including deficiency of riboflavin or vitamin B6, both of which are required for synthesis of nicotinamide from tryptophan, may be important. 

In most outbreaks of pellagra, twice as many women as men are affected, probably the result of inhibition of tryptophan metabolism by estrogen metabolites.

Option B & Option C: Contact dermatitis & Drug induced dermatitis not leading to above features.

Option D: In experimental animals, vitamin E deficiency results in resorption of fetuses and testicular atrophy. Dietary deficiency of vitamin E in human beings is unknown, although patients with severe fat malabsorption, cystic fibrosis and some forms of chronic liver disease suffer deficiency because they are unable to absorb or transport the vitamin, leading to nerve and muscle membrane damage. Premature infants are born with inadequate reserves of the vitamin. The erythrocyte membranes are abnormally fragile as a result of lipid peroxidation, leading to hemolytic anemia.

questions.text: In MSUD (maple syrup urine disorder) which of the following is not restricted:
questions.solution:
MSUD (maple syrup urine disorder) is a Metabolic disorder of branched-chain amino acid catabolism. As the name implies, the odor of urine in maple syrup urine disease (branched-chain ketonuria, or MSUD) suggests maple syrup, or burnt sugar. The biochemical defect in MSUD involves the α-keto acid decarboxylase complex. Plasma and urinary levels of leucine, isoleucine, valine, and their α-keto acids and α-hydroxy acids (reduced α-keto acids) are elevated, but the urinary keto acids derived principally from leucine.

Signs and symptoms of MSUD often include fatal ketoacidosis, neurological derangements, mental retardation, and a maple syrup odor of urine. The mechanism of toxicity is unknown.

Early diagnosis by enzymatic analysis is essential to avoid brain damage and early mortality by replacing dietary protein by an amino acid mixture that lacks leucine, isoleucine, and valine.

Option B, Option C & Option D: valine, leucine & isoleucine are branched chain amino acids, which are restricted.

Option A: Methionine is sulphur containing amino acids, and should not be restricted in MSUD.

questions.text: All are true regarding telomerase, Except:
questions.solution:
The ends of each chromosome contain structures called telomeres. Telomeres consist of short TG-rich repeats. Human telomeres have a variable number of repeats of the sequence 5′-TTAGGG-3′, which can extend for several kilobases. The telomeres of normal cells shorten on repeated cell division, which may result in cell death.

The enzyme telomerase replicates telomeres and is often expressed in cancer cells, helping them to evade cell death.

Telomerase, a multisubunit RNA template containing complex related to viral RNA-dependent DNA polymerases (reverse transcriptases), is the enzyme responsible for telomere synthesis and thus for maintaining the length of the telomere. Since telomere shortening has been associated with both malignant transformation and aging, this enzyme has become an attractive target for cancer chemotherapy and drug development.

Option A: Telomerase has Reverse transcriptase activity (RNA-dependent DNA polymerases)

Option B: Telomerase found only in Eukaryotes

Option C: Telomerase maintain telomere length and so maintain chromosome length

Option D: DNA fidelity is not maintained, as there is no proofreading activity or repair mechanism associated with telomerase.

questions.text: Ammonia is detoxified in the brain, by leading to formation of?
questions.solution:
Option A: Formation of glutamine in the brain is catalyzed by mitochondrial glutamine synthetase. Since amide bond synthesis is coupled to the hydrolysis of ATP to ADP and Pi , the reaction strongly favors glutamine synthesis. During catalysis, glutamate attacks the γ-phosphoryl group of ATP, forming γ-glutamyl phosphate and ADP. Following deprotonation of NH4 +, NH3 attacks γ-glutamyl phosphate, and glutamine and Pi are released. In addition to providing glutamine to serve as a carrier of nitrogen, carbon and energy between organs, glutamine synthetase plays a major role both in ammonia detoxification and in acid-base homeostasis.

Option B: In liver ammonia finally converted into Urea.

Option C: Alanine is involved in the Glucose-alanine cycle. Alanine is synthesized in muscle by transamination of glucose-derived pyruvate, released into the bloodstream, and taken up by the liver. In the liver, the carbon skeleton of alanine is reconverted to glucose and released into the bloodstream, where it is available for uptake by muscle and resynthesis of alanine.

Option D: Arginine is not involved in ammonia detoxification in the liver.

questions.text: Anticoagulant in grey container for glucose estimation:
questions.solution:
Option A: Anticoagulant in light blue colour container is sodium citrate, which is commonly used for coagulation studies.

Option B: Anticoagulant in grey container for glucose estimation is Potassium oxalate.

Option C: Antiglycolytic agent in grey container for glucose estimation is Sodium fluoride (NaF). It chelates Mg and inhibits enolase enzyme in glycolysis, so stop glycolysis and prevent reduction of sugar which transporting sample to laboratory.

Option D: EDTA ccontaining vacutainer are usually lavender blue in colour. It is commonly used for whole blood/haematology study.

questions.text: In Pompe's disease, the enzyme deficient is?
questions.solution:
Option A: Lysosomal α1 → 4 and α1 → 6 glucosidase (Acid maltase) deficiency leads to Pompe’s disease which is characterized by accumulation of glycogen in lysosomes: juvenile-onset variant, muscle hypotonia, death from heart failure by age 2; adult-onset variant, muscle dystrophy.

Option B: Muscle glycogen phosphorylase deficiency leads to McArdle syndrome which is characterized by Poor exercise tolerance; muscle glycogen abnormally high; blood lactate very low after exercise.

Option C: Muscle and erythrocyte phosphofructokinase 1 deficiency lead to Tarui disease, which is characterized by Poor exercise tolerance; abnormally high muscle glycogen (2.5-4%); blood lactate very low after exercise and hemolytic anemia.

Option D: Lactate dehydrogenase is an enzyme involved in anaerobic glycolysis. Under anaerobic conditions, the NADH cannot be reoxidized through the respiratory chain, and pyruvate is reduced to lactate catalyzed by lactate dehydrogenase.

A rare genetic glycogen storage disease characterized by either lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) M- or H-subunit deficiency.

Lactate dehydrogenase A deficiency (sometimes called glycogen storage disease XI) characterized by LDH M-subunit deficiency. Individual have exertional fatigue and muscle pain, cramps during exercise (exercise intolerance), can be accompanied by rhabdomyolysis and myoglobinuria.

Lactate dehydrogenase-B deficiency: Individuals with this type typically do not exhibit any signs or symptoms related to the condition. They do not experience difficulty with physical activity or specific physical features associated with the deficiency.

Glycogen storage Diseases

Glycogen storage disease is a generic term to describe a group of inherited disorders characterized by deposition of an abnormal type or quantity of glycogen in tissues, or failure to mobilize glycogen.

questions.text: Steps of polymerase chain reaction:
questions.solution:
PCR is a method of amplifying a target sequence of DNA. The development of PCR has revolutionized the ways in which both DNA and RNA can be studied. PCR provides a sensitive, selective, and extremely rapid means of amplifying any desired sequence of DNA. Specificity is based on the use of two oligonucleotide primers that hybridize to complementary sequences on opposite strands of DNA and flank the target sequence.

The DNA sample is first heat denatured (>90°C) to separate the two strands of the template DNA containing the target sequence; the primers, added in excess, are allowed to anneal to the DNA (typically at 50-75°C) in order to generate the required template-primer complex. Subsequently, each strand is copied by a DNA polymerase, starting at the primer sites in the presence of all four dXTPs. The two DNA strands each serve as a template for the synthesis of new DNA from the two primers.

Repeated cycles of heat denaturation, annealing of the primers to their complementary sequences, and extension of the annealed primers with DNA polymerase result in the exponential amplification of DNA segments of defined length. Product DNA doubles with each PCR cycle. DNA synthesis is catalyzed by a heat-stable DNA polymerase purified from one of a number of different thermophilic bacteria, organisms that grow at 70 to 80°C. Thermostable DNA polymerases withstand short incubations at over 90°, temperatures required to completely denature DNA. These thermostable DNA polymerases have made automation of PCR possible. DNA sequences as short as 50 to 100 bp and as long as 10 kb can readily be amplified by PCR. Twenty cycles provide an amplification of 106 (ie, 220) and 30 cycles, 109 (230). Each cycle takes ≤5 to 10 minutes so that even large DNA molecules can be amplified fairly rapidly.

So the correct sequence is Denaturation → Annealing → Elongation, so option B is correct.

choices.text: When sugars are different from one another, in configuration with regard to a single carbon atom, along with the reference carbon atom, they are called epimers
Mannose is epimer of Glucose at 2nd Carbon
Galactose is epimer of glucose at 4th Carbon
Mannose and Galactose are not epimers of glucose

questions.text: All of the following is true about Epimer except
questions.solution:
• A) When sugars are different from one another, in configuration with regard to a single carbon atom, along with the reference carbon atom, they are called epimers: This statement is true and defines the concept of epimers.
  • B) Mannose is epimer of Glucose at 2nd Carbon: This statement is true. Mannose and glucose differ in their configuration at the second carbon atom.
  • C) Galactose is epimer of glucose at 4th Carbon: This statement is also true. Galactose and glucose differ in their configuration at the fourth carbon atom.

So, the only statement that is not true is option D, which states that Mannose and Galactose are not epimers. In fact, they are epimers of glucose, but at different carbon atoms (Mannose at the second carbon and Galactose at the fourth carbon).

choices.text: The conversion of glucose to lactate requires the presence of oxygen.
Hexokinase is important in hepatic glucose metabolism only in the absorptive period following consumption of a carbohydrate-containing meal.
Fructose 2, 6-bisphosphate is a potent inhibitor of phosphofructokinase.
The rate-limiting reactions are also the irreversible reactions.

questions.text: Which one of the following statements concerning glycolysis is correct?
questions.solution:
• Hexokinase, phosphofructokinase and pyruvate kinase are all catalysing irreversible reactions and are the regulated steps in glycolysis.
  • The conversion of glucose to lactate (anaerobic glycolysis) is a process that does not involve a net oxidation or reduction and, thus, oxygen is not required.
  • Glucokinase (not hexokinase) is important in hepatic glucose metabolism only in the absorptive period following consumption of a carbohydrate-containing meal.
  • Fructose 2,6-bisphosphate is a potent activator (not inhibitor) of phosphofructokinase.
  • The conversion of glucose to lactate yields two ATP but no net production of NADH.

questions.text: In the fed state, major fate of glucose-6-phosphate in liver is:
questions.solution:
• The uptake of glucose into the liver is independent of insulin, but liver has an isoenzyme of hexokinase (glucokinase) with a high Km, so that as the concentration of glucose entering the liver increases, so does the rate of synthesis of glucose-6-phosphate.
  • This is in excess of the liver's requirement for energy-yielding metabolism, and is used mainly for synthesis of glycogen.
  • In both liver and skeletal muscle, insulin acts to stimulate glycogen synthetase and inhibit glycogen phosphorylase.
  • The uptake of glucose into the liver GLUT 2 is independent of insulin.

questions.text: Hormones that cause an increase in free fatty acid levels in the blood are all of the above except?
questions.solution:
Hormones that increase lipolysis are :

  • Epinephrine
  • Norepinephrine
  • Glucagon
  • ACTH
  • TSH
  • MSH
  • GH and
  • Vasopressin

Whereas, insulin inhibits lipolysis by inhibiting hormone-sensitive lipae (hsl) and causes decrease in free fatty acid levels in the blood.

questions.text: All is/are sphingolipidosis disease except?
The lipoprotein that moves the fastest towards the anode is?
questions.solution:
The placement of the lipoproteins in electrophoresis depends on the charge and mass of the lipoproteins. The higher the protein content, the faster the lipoprotein moves.

In this aspect, HDL travels the fastest and towards the anode and Chylomicrons remain at the origin.

The sequence in electrophoresis is as follows:

questions.text: Which of the following vitamin deficiencies can lead to purine deficiency states in human?
questions.solution:
Sources of the nitrogen and carbon atoms of the purine ring:

C2 of purine ring is contributed by N10 formyl tetrahydrofolate, whereas C8 of purine ring is contributed by N5 N10 methenyl tetrahydrofolate. So derivatives of tetrahydrofolate, which is produced from folic acid, plays an important role in de novo biosynthesis of purine nucleotides. De novo synthesis is a major pathway which provides nucleotides to tissues for their physiological needs.

So purine deficiency states, while rare in humans, but generally occurs in a deficiency of folic acid.

So any compounds that inhibit formation of tetrahydrofolate and therefore block purine synthesis have been used in cancer chemotherapy.

Option A: Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) deficiency can lead to scurvy. It is not involved in purine biosynthesis reactions.

Option B: Purine deficiency can occur secondary to folic acid deficiency.

Option C: Pyridoxine has no role in purine biosynthesis.

Option D: Calcitriol (vitamin D) also has no role in purine biosynthesis. Vitamin D deficiency can lead to rickets.

choices.text: Active in tissues involved in eicosanoid metabolism

questions.text: All of the following is true about peroxidase enzyme, except:
questions.solution:
Option A: Peroxidases are found in milk in high quantity.

Option B: Peroxidases are also found in leukocytes, platelets, and other tissues involved in eicosanoid metabolism.

Option C: Prosthetic group present in peroxidase is protoheme

Option D: Peroxidases Reduce Peroxides Using Various Electron Acceptors

In the reaction catalyzed by peroxidase, hydrogen peroxide is reduced at the expense of several substances that act as electron acceptors, such as ascorbate (vitamin C), quinones, and cytochrome c.

The reaction catalyzed by peroxidase is complex, but the overall reaction is as follows:

questions.text: Non steroidal anti inflammatory drugs, such as aspirin act by inhibiting the activity of the enzyme:
questions.solution:
Drugs acting as inhibitors COX

  • NSAID
    • Aspirin: Inhibits COX-1 and COX-2.
    • Indomethacin and ibuprofen-inhibit cyclooxyge- nases by competing with arachidonate.
    • Coxibs: Selectively inhibit COX-2
    • Some coxibs have been withdrawn or suspended from the market due to undesirable side effects and safety issues.

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms are associated with covalent modification
questions.solution:
Covalent Modification

  • Method of regulation of Enzyme activity
  • Addition or removal of a group by making or breaking a covalent bond
  • By covalent modification enzyme activity is either increased or decreased.

Two types of covalent modification

  1. Irreversible: Partial proteolysis/zymogen activation
  2. Reversible: Addition/removal of a particular group.

Common methods of reversible covalent modification

  • Phosphorylation/dephosphorylation [Most Common covalent modification]
  • Methylation
  • Adenylation
  • ADP ribosylation

questions.text: An isoenzyme variant of the following enzymes appear during pregnancy
questions.solution:
• Physically distinct forms of the same enzymes, but catalyse the same reaction
  • Different molecular forms of the same enzyme synthesized from the same or various tissues.

Isoenzymes of Alkaline Phosphatase (ALP)

choices.text: Help in the conversion of cyanide to thiocyanate

questions.text: Sulfur of cysteine are not used/utilized in the body for the following process/product:
questions.solution:
Methionine is an essential amino acid, so it cannot be synthesized from Cysteine.

  • Sulfur of cysteine is donated by sulfur of methionine.
  • This is called trans-sulfuration reaction.
  • PLP is the coenzyme of transsulfuration.
  • The reaction is catalyzed by Cystathionine beta Synthase and Cystathionase enzyme.

questions.text: In forming 3D structure following factors help except:
questions.solution:
• Amino Acid sequence determines the tertiary structure of proteins
  • Side chains help in the formation of bonds involved in tertiary structure of proteins
  • Interaction of polypeptide also helps the three dimensional structure of proteins
  • Chaperone helps in protein folding; hence it helps in three dimensional structure.
  • But Peptide bond helps in the primary structure.

questions.text: Amino acid produced by adding hydroxyl group to benzene ring chain of phenylalanine:
questions.solution:
• Special group in phenylalanine is benzene ring.
  • Special group in Tyrosine is phenol ring.
  • The enzyme that hydroxylates Phenylalanine to Tyrosine is Phenylalanine Hydroxylase.

questions.text: Which of the following metabolic defect is seen in Type I Tyrosinemia?
questions.solution: Untreated acute and chronic tyrosinosis leads to death from liver failure. Therapy employs a diet low in tyrosine and phenylalanine.

questions.text: The amino acid which serves as a carrier of ammonia from skeletal muscle to liver is:
questions.solution: The transport form of ammonia from most tissues including brain is glutamine but the transport form of ammonia from skeletal muscle is alanine.

questions.text: NADP-linked dehydrogenases are involved in all of the following metabolic pathway, except:
questions.solution:
• Many Dehydrogenases Depend on Nicotinamide Coenzymes
  • These dehydrogenases use NAD+ or nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NADP+) or both. They are formed in the body from the vitamin niacin.
  • Generally, NAD-linked dehydrogenases catalyze oxidoreduction reactions occur in the oxidative pathways of metabolism, particularly in glycolysis and the citric acid cycle (Option C).
  • NADP-linked dehydrogenases are found characteristically in biosynthetic pathways where reductive reactions are required, as in the extra mitochondrial pathway of fatty acid synthesis (Option A) and steroid synthesis (Option D) and also in the pentose phosphate pathway (Option B).

So Option C is correct answer.

choices.text: The synthesis of larger and more complex compounds from smaller precursors is called anabolic pathways
Catabolic pathways are pathways that are involved in the breakdown of larger molecules
Pathways which act as links between the anabolic and catabolic pathways are called amphibolic pathways

questions.text: Metabolism is an important aspect in medicine. Which of the following is wrong regarding this?
questions.solution:
• Anabolic pathways are those involved in the synthesis of larger and more complex compounds from smaller precursors.
  • These reactions require energy input and are endergonic (not exothermic).
  • For example, protein synthesis from amino acids or glycogen synthesis from glucose.
  • Hence, the statement that anabolic pathways are exothermic is incorrect.

Related important points and concepts:

  • Catabolic pathways involve the breakdown of larger molecules, are oxidative, exergonic, and produce ATP.
  • Amphibolic pathways, such as the citric acid cycle, serve as links between anabolic and catabolic processes.
  • Overall, metabolism includes both energy-generating and energy-consuming pathways tightly regulated to maintain homeostasis.

Explanation of other options:

The synthesis of larger and more complex compounds from smaller precursors is called Anabolic pathways (Option A): Correct; refers to biosynthetic reactions.

Catabolic pathways are pathways that are involved in the breakdown of larger molecules (Option B): Correct; these reactions release energy.

Pathways which act as links between the anabolic and catabolic pathways are called Amphibolic pathways (Option D): Correct; e.g., TCA cycle.

Key Takeaways:

  • Anabolic = building up = endergonic (requires energy)
  • Catabolic = breaking down = exergonic (releases energy)
  • Amphibolic = dual role in catabolism and anabolism
